source.description: Select hairpins that that have high “G_eff” and a low “S_eff” and “unpred_offset_mean” to maximize on target effects and minimize off target effects.

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Genes with high-quality shRNAs tested in RNAi Data

source.description: A description of the table columns is provided below:

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Genes with high-quality shRNAs tested in RNAi Data

source.description:
Table of model parameters estimated for each shRNA (shRNAs are indexed by their targeting sequence) includes the following columns:
  1. Geff: Estimated gene knockdown efficacy of each shRNA (alpha_i).
  2. Seff: Estimated off-target efficacy of each shRNA (beta_i)
  3. unpred_offset_mean: Posterior mean of 'unpredicted' across-cell-line average off-target effect per shRNA (c_i)
  4. unpred_offset_sd: Posterior std dev of 'unpredicted' across-cell-line average off-target effect per shRNA (c_i)
  5. hairpin_offset_mean: Posterior mean of additive offset per shRNA and batch (theta_ik), averaged across batches k.
  6. hairpin_offset_sd: Posterior std dev of additive offset per shRNA and batch (theta_ik), averaged across batches (as sqrt())

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Genes with high-quality shRNAs tested in RNAi Data

source.description: NOTE: Not all genes have quality shRNA sequences from the shRNA libraries and additional shRNA sequences may need to be designed and tested empirically. It is our experience that some genes may not have suitable shRNA sequences unless 10-20 sequences are tested. In those cases RNAi may be less tractable than alternative experimental systems to inactivate a gene or protein product, such as CRISPR or degron tags.

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Genes without shRNAs quality control from RNAi Data

source.description: It is recommended that you design multiple on-target sequences for each gene. Some helpful tools are below:

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description:
To clone shRNA oligonucleotides we prefer the
Cellecta shRNA Tet Inducible Expression Vector
. The general design for this vector is as follows:

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description:
5’-accgG-(21sense)-(Stem-Loop-Stem)-(21antisense)-TTTT-3’
Sense oligo:
5’-accgGNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNGTTAATATTCATAGCNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNTTTT-3’
Antisense oligo:
5’cgaaAAAANNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNGCTATGAATATTAACNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNC-3’

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description: The sense strand is the shRNA target sequence from the Achilles/DRIVE library found in the “D2_combined_hp_data.csv” file

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description: To design a seed control, nucleotides in the 9-11 position in the oligos should be altered to the complement nucleotides. This should disrupt on-target binding, but maintains knockdown of off-target genes.

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector
1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description: Notice in the above example that the seed (nucleotides 2-8) remains constant between the on-target shRNA and the seed, hence these sequences being called seed-matched controls.

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description:
In certain cases, C9-11 seed controls retain partial on-target knockdown. In those cases it is possible to design seed controls with additional base pair alterations to further reduce on-target gene affinity.
(For example, controls with positions 9-13 nt can be mutated that retain the seed sequence).

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description:
Link to
C9-11 design tool

source.title: 1. shRNA Selection and Evaluation: Cloning shRNAs into Tet Inducible Cellecta vector

source.description: Once you have designed 3-5 targeting sequences and their corresponding seed controls, clone sequences into the Cellecta tet-inducible vector and lentivirally transduce cells to create cell lines stably expressing inducible shRNA vector.

source.title: 2. Evaluation of KD by qRT-PCR or western blot

source.description: We evaluate on-target knockdown performance of each shRNA and seed control. We use standard lab techniques for both qPCR and western blotting to determine the effect of knockdown in the cell lines of interest.

source.title: 4. Assessing cell viability effects with 10-14 day Foci Formation and 7 day Cell Titer Glo assays: CV Assay

source.description: To determine the short-term and long-term viability effects of the on-target and seed shRNAs in vitro, we use 7-Day CTGs and Crystal Violet Assays. The 7-Day CTG provides a quantitative short-term readout, while the crystal violet assay provides long-term qualitative data. Both assays are important when assessing on-target viability effects and seed toxicity, as the potency and viability timeline of shRNAs can vary widely between cell lines; seed effects that appear minimal at seven days may have a larger viability effect at the 14-day time point or vice versa. Additionally, seed effects and on-target viability that appear strong in one cell line may not have the same phenotype in another. Therefore, vigorous testing of each cell line is essential in determining its use for future in vivo experiments.

source.title: 4. Assessing cell viability effects with 10-14 day Foci Formation and 7 day Cell Titer Glo assays: CV Assay

source.description: Trypsinize and count the on-target shRNA and associated seed control cell lines

Bold- Fast Growing Cell Line

source.title: 4. CTG readout

source.description: Monitor the – dox wells to ensure the wells are confluent by day 7

source.title: 4. CTG readout

source.description: Add CTG reagent and readout by the Envision

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Continuously monitor the 24 well plates to determine when the -dox wells become 100% confluent. Once the 24 well plates become confluent, fix and stain the plate according to the below protocol.

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Gently aspirate the media and add 250 uL of 1X PBS to wash the wells. Add PBS to the sides of the wells to not dislodge any cells

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Aspirate the PBS and add 250 uL of 4% Paraformeldahyde in 1X PBS. Leave the plates on the shaker for 15 minutes to completely fix the cells

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Remove the 4% paraformeldahyde and wash wells with 250 uL of water.

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Remove the water and add 250 uL Crystal Violet to each well. Leave plates on shaker for 20 minutes to stain cells

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Remove the crystal violet stain and wash wells multiple times with water until the residual crystal violet is completely removed.

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: Let the plates dry for 24 hours and then image these plates on a scanner (600 dpi, increased brightness).

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description: To quantify the crystal violet stain, add 250 uL of 10% acetic acid to each of the wells. Place plates on the shaker for 20 minutes to remove crystal violet stain from cells

source.title: 5. Crystal Violet Fixation

source.description:
In a 96-well plate, take 25 uL from each well and dilute it in 75 uL water according to the plate map below. Measure the OD at 600 nm.

description: Proper design of shRNA sequences can be challenging, requiring empirical testing of up to 10-20 shRNA sequences. To address these issues, we leverage data from RNAi loss of function screens aggregated by the Cancer Dependency Map project (Depmap.org). We identify and prioritize shRNAs more likely to have both strong “on-target” effects and lower off-target effects ("shRNA Seed effects"). Throughout this protocol, we detail how to identify top shRNAs from these large-scale screens, and provide guidance on the design of seed-matched controls. We then describe how to evaluate the selected shRNAs to identify the shRNAs with the maximal differential between on-target and off target effects. It is important to test multiple shRNAs and their corresponding seed control sequences to ensure they do not retain partial on target activity or have broad off-target toxicity. shRNAs and their seed controls can have different viability effects depending on the design, and the cell line being used, so it is crucial to rigorously test multiple shRNAs in multiple cell lines. If used properly, shRNAs can be a great genetic perturbation reagent for target validation, particularly for inducible in vivo experiments.
